course.name: Done is better - Build What Matters

questions.question: You are handed a messy situation (inbox, project, relationship). What is the first step?
options: Apply: decompose, find leverage, name the next move; write the new structure in 5 bullets or fewer
Fix everything at once without understanding what matters most or prioritizing
Add more process and structure without identifying the core issues or leverage points
Leave it as is and hope it resolves itself over time without intervention

questions.question: A manager inherits a chaotic project with 50 open tasks, no priorities, and unclear ownership. They decompose it into 5 areas, identify the leverage point, and name the next move. What does this demonstrate?
options: Moving from chaos to clarity: creating order through structure and priorities
Cleaning up only without changing the underlying structure
Reorganizing only without naming next steps or ownership
Delegating and leaving without documenting or clarifying

questions.question: You inherit a chaotic project with unclear priorities and no structure. How do you create order?
options: Decompose, find leverage, name the next move; write the new structure briefly
Add more steps and process without understanding what is essential or testable
Hold more meetings to discuss the mess without taking action or creating structure
Assign everything to others without creating structure or priorities or next steps

questions.question: Trying to fix everything at once in a messy situation often leads to:
options: Overwhelm and no clear progress; focus on structure and one next move
Faster resolution
Better results
No meaningful effect on outcomes

questions.question: Adding process for its own sake can result in:
options: More chaos; structure should serve clarity and the next move
More clarity
Faster execution
No significant downside in practice

questions.question: What should you leave behind when you exit a messy situation?
options: A clear next owner or next step; the situation clearer than you found it
A long report documenting everything without clear next steps or actionable items
Nothing; move on without leaving any structure or guidance for the next person
Only recommendations without identifying who will act on them or what comes next

questions.question: Pick one messy area. What should you produce?
options: Decompose, find leverage, name the next move; write the new structure in 5 bullets or fewer
A full plan with all details before taking any action or testing assumptions
A list of problems without identifying solutions or priorities or next steps
A meeting invite to discuss the mess without creating structure or clarity
